bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 7, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] informs Kean that he has found proof that a rental fee was paid by the U.S. military to use the Rojas family farm. He is thinking of purchasing Building No. 1 at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 7, 1940
div1.p:
In a day or two I will be returning, by registered express, your diary,
with a half dozen questions. It has been of tremendous value to me but more of this
tomorrow.

I am writing you hastily to tell you of the latest discovery. I sent my
memorandum to the Rojas family and, you remember, asked them about the possibility of
their having some sort of contract between Dr. Rojas and Reed or Agramonte. When I was
there, Mrs. Rojas knew of none, but since receiving my detailed memorandum, the family
has interested themselves and Miss Rojas has been hunting around the family records.
Last week she found some old day books of her father and in one of them were notations
written in her father's hand proving that the camp site was not ceded gratis, but that
a rental of $20.00 American gold monthly had been paid from and including November 9, 1900
to October 10, 1901, buildings nos. 1 and 2, to remain the property of the owner. Entries
in Dr. Rojas' journal-cash book were made regularly, the first check having been received
from “Major Mr. Reed” and subsequent checks from “Major J. R. Kean, the latter evidently
acting as disbursing quartermaster.” Miss Rojas excitedly phoned Moran, who airmailed me
at once this information. They are having it copied and translated for me and attested to,
and I am arranging also to have more definite proof; that is, actual photographs of the
entries.

In view of the stubbornness of the Cuban officials, including Dr. Angles,
to recognize their mistake and the correctness of my information to them, this record of
Dr. Rojas should act as final proof. Apparently you did not remember or at least did not
tell me that you had been involved in this transaction and I should be most grateful if
you could give me what information you remember. Doubtless, you kept records of these
transactions. Where are these now filed, and could we get them from the quartermaster or
War Department? The reason I am anxious to know is that I would like to plant the seeds of
a campaign during my Washington and Jefferson talk. Indeed, I have not told you all. Moran
revisited the site we investigated and has now decided that one of the shacks which we
thought could not have been either building no. 1 or 2, is in truth building no. 1 with
many renovations, mostly outside. Inside he found the tongued and grooved boards with weather
boarding on the outside and a lean-to addition which distorted the appearance entirely.
I am not yet willing to accept this, but nevertheless have written asking Pogolotti to
quietly sound out the price for the house and lot. I will personally buy it at once if we
can prove its historicity, to my satisfaction. I can assure you that I will buy it only
to protect it and as a first step in a quiet campaign among medical friends and institutions
proud of Reed, Lazear, etc. to raise enough money to restore it and memorialize it properly.
More of this later, I enclose a copy of Dr. Angles' recent letter. It is not too clear,
probably because of the translation but the ideals obvious, that i am entirely wrong, that the
San Jose farm has nothing to do with Camp Lazear, that Camp Lazear was right by the railroad
track near Camp Columbia and that the American followers of Reed robbed Finlay of all his
glory.
